“Els insults de «maricon» em van fer deixar la dansa, però l’assetjament seguia”
Un 80% dels alumnes han presenciat insults LGTBIfòbics i fins i tot pallisses, però només un 2% dels assetjats denuncien, segons la Taula del Tercer Sector

02 Nov 2019, 00:03

“Tot va començar quan vaig començar a fer dansa, als 9 o 10 anys”, explica Jordi Navarro. “Fèiem les classes en un lloc que tenia una vidriera, i els altres nens es quedaven allà mirant-nos despectivament. Vaig començar a pensar que fer dansa no estava bé per a un nen”, recorda. El Jordi tria amb molta cura les paraules per explicar com el van assetjar, de petit, per ser homosexual. Ara, als 21 anys, té molt clar com va empitjorar el problema. “Després de les mirades despectives van arribar els rumors i els insults de «maricon», i això em va poder: vaig deixar la dansa i em vaig apuntar a tenis, però l’assetjament va continuar”, explica. “Pensava «Aguanta, Jordi, que això s’acabarà», però passaven els anys i no s’acabava mai”, recorda.
El cas del Jordi és, també, el de molts altres nens. L’assetjament escolar per orientació sexual, identitat o expressió de gènere és el principal motiu d’insult, burla o rebuig als centres educatius, segons l’últim informe de la Taula del Tercer Sector, que es farà públic dimarts. L’estudi recull -a partir d’una mostra qualitativa de 300 estudiants d’institut- que el 80% de l’alumnat ha presenciat insults cap a persones LGTBI i un 12% reconeix haver-los dut a terme. Un 20% diu haver presenciat directament violència física i un 2% admet haver-la infligit. Entre les agressions més subtils, gairebé set de cada deu han presenciat rumors o comentaris pejoratius i un 12% reconeix haver-los fomentat.
Tot i això, aquest tipus d’assetjament poques vegades surt a la llum. Encara és una realitat invisible: només el 2% dels casos denunciats a l’Observatori contra l’Homofòbia (OCH) són en l’àmbit escolar. Els autors de l’informe creuen que el motiu és que, en el cas dels infants, la problemàtica es torna “molt més complexa” -sobretot fora de l’entorn escolar, on l’assetjament pot continuar sense control, com li va passar al Jordi- i es viu en silenci.
Sis anys de patiment en silenci
“El més normal és ocultar-ho i crear-te un personatge que s’assembla al dels altres, fins i tot actuar com una persona masclista i homòfoba”, corrobora el Jordi, que afegeix que va ser la seva manera de “protegir-se i sobreviure”. Ara, als 21 anys, celebra que ja no té problemes per explicar el que va passar, sobretot si això pot ajudar nens que ara passen pel mateix.
En el seu cas, l’assetjament es va produir fora de l’escola, durant les activitats extraescolars, i es va allargar sis anys. Durant aquest temps va patir burles, insults, agressions físiques com escopinades i fins i tot cops, i va caure en conductes que el van portar a flirtejar amb la marihuana i les autolesions. “Intentava encaixar en algun grup”, justifica. Mai va explicar res, ni als seus professors ni als seus pares, i va buscar les seves pròpies solucions. “A casa deia que m’havia posat en un embolic jo sol perquè havia pres la nòvia a algun dels nens”, reconeix. “I als nens [als agressors] els vaig arribar a dir que ja m’havia penedit d’apuntar-me a dansa, però tampoc em feia petit: els plantava cara -admet-. No demostrava mai que m’afectava: sempre em feia el fort”.
El Jordi explica que va assumir de molt petit que la seva orientació sexual estava “mal vista”. “Recordo preguntar què volia dir l’insult «maricon»:la resposta em va fer veure, inconscientment, que la meva condició sexual s’utilitza despectivament”, relata. “Sembla que no, però les expressions que s’utilitzen a l’escola fan molt de mal”, reflexiona. A la preadolescència ell es va arribar a convertir en “el que tenia més nòvies” i en el més “ fiestero ”. “Et preguntes per què no estàs dient el que et passa i és perquè no ho acceptes, per no preocupar -reflexiona-, per moltes coses”.
Un final de pel·lícula
Els autors de l’informe conclouen que l’assetjament per LGTBI-fòbies es cronifica per les dificultats de comunicació pròpies de l’edat, la normalització de l’homofòbia o la por a les represàlies o al “contagi de l’estigma” que tenen els altres alumnes. I recomanen no tractar-los com a “problemes individuals”. També calen referents i xarxes de suport. El Jordi va trobar els seus als 18 anys: “Vaig veure una escena a la sèrie Merlí on un noi gai pujava a la taula, a classe, per dir-ho en veu alta i acabar amb els rumors”, explica amb un somriure. Aquella nit va devorar “moltíssims capítols” i l’endemà ell va fer el mateix a classe. “Fins i tot vaig projectar a la pantalla una foto amb la meva parella”, diu rient. Aleshores el Jordi ja feia dos anys que estudiava a Barcelona, allunyat dels que l’havien assetjat. Un gest que va servir com a desllorigador: el mateix dia, a la nit, ho va explicar tot als seus pares i, poc després, va participar en un programa de cites a la televisió. “Així ho va saber tot el poble de cop”.
Les xifres d’una problemàtica invisible
L’estudi de la Taula del Tercer Sector assegura que l’assetjament escolar per orientació sexual, identitat o expressió de gènere és el primer motiu d’insults i rebuig als instituts. Un 20% dels alumnes admeten haver vist, fins i tot, pallisses.
Tot i que aquest tipus d’assetjament és molt comú als centres educatius, del total de denúncies que rep l’Observatori contra l’Homofòbia, actualment només el 2% són en l’àmbit escolar. És una problemàtica invisibilitzada i normalitzada.

"The insults of" maricon "made me stop the dance, but the harassment followed"
80% of the students witnessed LGTBIphobic insults and even beatings, but only 2% of the harassed report, according to the Third Sector Table

02 Nov 2019, 00:03

"Everything started when I started dancing, at 9 or 10 years," explains Jordi Navarro. "We did the classes in a place that had a showcase, and the other children remained there looking contemptuously to us. I started to think that doing dance was not good for a child, "he remembers. Jordi carefully selected the words to explain how he was harassed, as a child, to be homosexual. Now, at the age of 21, he is very clear how the problem worsens. "After the contemptuous glances came the rumors and the insults of" maricon ", and this could have allowed me: I left the dance and I signed up for tennis, but the harassment continued," he explains. "I thought," Hold on, Jordi, that this will end ", but the years passed and never finished," he remembers.
Jordi's case is also that of many other children. School bullying due to sexual orientation, identity or gender expression is the main reason for insult, mockery or refusal in schools, according to the latest report from the Third Sector Board, which will be released Tuesday. The study includes - based on a qualitative sample of 300 students of institute - that 80% of the students have witnessed insults towards LGBT people and 12% recognize that they have carried out them. 20% say that they have witnessed direct physical violence and 2% admits having inflicted it. Among the most subtle assaults, almost seven out of ten have seen rumors or pejorative comments and 12% acknowledged having promoted them.
However, this type of harassment rarely comes to light. It is still an invisible reality: only 2% of the cases reported at the Homophobia Observatory (OCH) are in the school sphere. The authors of the report believe that the reason is that, in the case of children, the problem becomes "much more complex" - especially outside the school environment, where harassment can continue without control, as it happened to Jordan - he lives in silence.
Six years of silent suffering
"The most normal thing is to hide it and create a character that resembles that of others, even acting like a homosexual and chaperonist person," corroborates Jordi, who adds that it was his way of " stay and survive ". Now, at the age of 21, he celebrates that he no longer has problems explaining what happened, especially if this can help children who now pass through it.
In your case, harassment occurred outside school, during extracurricular activities, and it lasted six years. During this time he suffered ridicules, insults, physical assaults as bullies and even blows, and he fell into behaviors that led him to flirt with marijuana and self-injuries. "He tried to fit in some group," he justifies. He never explained anything, neither to his teachers nor to his parents, and sought his own solutions. "At home he said that he had put me in a mess just because he had taken the girlfriend to one of the children," he acknowledges. "And to the children [to the aggressors] I got to say that I had already repented of pointing to dance, but neither did I do little: I was standing up," he admits. It never showed that it affected me: it always made me strong. "
Jordi explains that he assumed that his sexual orientation was "very bad" at a very small age. "I remember asking what the" maricon "insult meant: the answer made me see, unconsciously, that my sexual condition was used contemptuously," he says. "It does not seem like that, but the expressions that are used in the school do a lot of damage," he reflects. In pre-adolescence he got to become "the one who had more children" and in the more "party". "You ask why you are not saying what is happening to you and that is because you do not accept it, not to worry -frequently- for many things."
A movie ending
The authors of the report conclude that LGBT-phobic harassment is timed due to age-related communication difficulties, the normalization of homophobia or the fear of reprisals or the "stigma contagion" that have the other students. And they recommend not to treat them as "individual problems". Referrals and support networks are also needed. Jordi found his at the age of 18: "I saw a scene in the Merlí series where a gay boy would go upstairs, in class, to say it out loud and end the rumors," he says with a smile. That night he devoured "many chapters" and on the following day he did the same in class. "I even projected a photo with my partner on the screen," she says laughing. At that time Jordi had been studying in Barcelona for two years, away from those who had been besieged. A gesture that served as a disorientation: on the same day, at night, he explained everything to his parents and, shortly after, he participated in a television show program. "That's how the whole town knew about it."
The figures of an invisible problem
The study of the Third Sector Table says that school bullying due to sexual orientation, identity or gender expression is the first reason for insults and rejection of institutes. 20% of students admit to having even beaten.
Although this type of harassment is very common in schools, of the total number of complaints received by the Observatory against Homophobia, currently only 2% are in the school setting. It is an invisible and standardized problem.
